On Tue, 16 Nov 2004 02:18:47 -0000, Kenneth Stanley
<kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> What are the eye's motions like when looking over fingerprints?  It
> would be really interesting to see movies of the the eye examining a
> fingerprint.

Well, there you go.  I've uploaded another Flash movie,
"left_loop2.swf" into the files section of the group:

http://f6.grp.yahoofs.com/v1/4AeaQcXY5lgs-UB2o8GRVhmNYECb-SIVrixEfUUQ7ZnnUfHOWucQ1WZHRBRPJTxW6aEQJLDF0w2xu1KtIUF1Ig/left_loop2.swf

This particular network is evolved to recognize the left loop class of
fingerprints.  Here are some samples of the different classes:

http://www.nist.gov/srd/fing_img.htm

For now we're just focusing on the four-class problem, lumping
together arch and tented arch (which together only make up about 5-6%
of fingerprints in the natural population anyway).

So if you watch the movie, you'll see that the eye always seems to
zoom in on the core of the print, then oscillate in that core area. 
For left loops, though, it zooms into the core, then always drifts
away to the left.  It's interesting to note that it pretty easily
distinguishes between right loops and arches, while the class that
seems difficult to distinguish between the most is whorl.

I didn't include the affinity representation in the uploaded movie,
but with whorls, the eye begins to drift the left, spitting out high
affinities, but then apparently notices that the ridge lines don't
continue to slant the same way they do in a left loop pattern, so the
eye returns to the core of the whorl and oscillates.

Now, I actually thought that loops would be more likely to be confused
with arches, but apparently the eye doesn't have much problem making
that distinction.

One of the things I'm really pleased about is that the neural network
doesn't seem to have a problem handling images where the contrast
levels are quite different.  We did a few brief experiments with
fingerprint images that we had done some preprocessing on, to try to
filter out some of the noise and heighten the contrast of the ridge
lines to the background, but that doesn't seem to really affect the
evolving fitness much.  So it's nice that the system seems to be able
to handle raw images.  Most other systems do a lot of
computationally-expensive pre-processing of the images.  In fact, one
of the most successful research projects we read about take up to 10
seconds per print for classification.  I don't know what kind of
accuracy rate we'll end up with, but we'll definitely be able to beat
that by a long way.

Derek
